HomeAbout UsNews, company reports and blogBlogLife at REAOne year at REA: Lessons, Growth, and Gratitude 



One year at REA: Lessons, Growth, and Gratitude



Article by Anmol Kaur
Published on 11th Sep 2023 — Read in  5 mins



Share




Tweet about it





Share this on LinkedIn





Share this on Facebook













Well folks, it is official. I’ve survived a whole year at my first ADULT job ever! Cue celebratory music!!
It feels like just yesterday I was nervously starting my first day on the job, wondering if I had what it takes to be security person. After being at school for all my life, *cough* (18 years without a gap year) I wasn’t sure if the school life had prepared me enough for joining the workforce.
The most accurate way to summarise how I was feeling entering the corporate world would be like:

The key driving factor of my decision to come to REA was the culture and the people. These are most important to me, as I have always wanted to feel a sense of belonging and purpose. After my first month at REA, I felt seen and important.
So, come along with me as I share some things I have learnt in the past year.
The beginning…
When I was at school, all sorts of things, milestones, and consequences, were straightforward and with clear measures of success. From my experience, success at school was mostly black and white; if you didn’t demonstrate the steps for your answer, you would not get the marks. I liked that. I became accustomed to having my goals quantifiable and clear.

When I entered the corporate world, I struggled with not having any structured syllabus telling me what to do and what my aim should be for the quarter. I found it quite hard to come up with my own milestones. Measuring success became a bit of grey area for me. It took some time to get used to different ways to hold myself accountable, to motivate myself and to define what success looks like for me. After a while, I started to join the dots. I figured out the agile approach to just “do the project that interests you”. I figured out how that adds value to epics, any interdependences and team’s OKRS. It finally made some sense!
Initially, I was very intimidated starting in a team of all male engineers. Being a woman in STEM, I had varied experiences back in the university group project days (haven’t we all?)

Pun intended.
But, to my surprise, I felt welcomed, heard, and acknowledged. I realised that I didn’t have to fit in. Everyone around me provided the space for me to grow, where I could be my true self. I am at a loss for words to express the compassion, kindness, and understanding shown by my teammates. I feel so lucky to have the opportunity to work and learn alongside them daily. I still remember the celebrations when I did my first Git Push, being challenged for even considering working past 5pm, and the genuine appreciation & understanding I received when I made mistakes.
Even within such a supportive environment, the feeling of imposter syndrome did creep up in me. In the beginning, I felt I had nothing to add to the conversations others were having. That sense of accomplishment at the end of the day was hard to get, as most of my day was filled with googling what others are saying. Even some of the jokes, I couldn’t understand why they were funny!

Thankfully, the amazing folks I work with provided me with so much support. I started to feel like I was getting the hang of it all. Even if it made me uncomfortable, I never stopped asking questions. I believe that is one of the hardest but most valuable things anyone can do: ask good questions. I think imposter syndrome is a feeling that doesn’t completely go away, but engaging in things that challenge those thoughts can help.

One year on…
Time has flown by quickly since the day I joined, it has been a year already!
Even after studying cyber security for 2.5 years, I realised there is a big gap between studying and practical application in the real world. In the last year, I have learned to develop opinions on tools, understand how projects, epics, OKRs go hand in hand, pick up a few little annoying GUI features of tools/apps I use regularly, become more detail oriented, use analytical thinking and incorporate a security mindset in my day-to-day life.
To explain the big words I used above, I have one little memory to share that will summarise it all. During my first REAio, I excitedly mentioned a burning idea I had to one of my favourite co-workers (Hola amigo Jim). Being the birthday enthusiast, I shared the idea of having a Slackbot that will automatically throw a message in the team channel and wish them Happy Birthday! Jim appreciated my idea and enthusiasm and asked me some series of questions (like he always does).
He asked me:

Shouldn’t birthdays be kept a secret, as people use it for passwords? Umm, yes.
Do you give your real birthdate everywhere? Umm, yes.


Which made me stop and realise how much that ACTUALLY MAKES SENSE!! Thanks to Jim, since that conversation I have made my family & friends change their emails as they include their birthdates. Now, every time I am invited to a birthday party l can’t help but say things like, “better be no one keeping a note of your birthdate” which leads to me telling people stop putting their birthdates in Instagram bios or their emails.
It is safe to say that I am a changed person with a different, more realistic mindset and on I am on the right track to becoming a better security professional.
Huge shoutout to all of my team for supporting my learning and growth over the past year at REA.
Join our Talent Community today to stay up to date on all things Careers at REA.
